context.description:
Key Topics:



- New Outlook Adoption: David Gorelik discussed the ongoing adoption of the new Outlook across various segments, including consumer, education, and commercial sectors. He highlighted the organic growth and the toggle feature that allows users to try out the new product alongside the classic version. 1 

- Feedback and NDA: Caitlin Hart emphasized the importance of feedback and the volatile nature of changes in industries like FSI. She encouraged participants to deliver feedback, which will be incorporated into the new Outlook. David Gorelik confirmed that all participants are under NDA, allowing for a more candid conversation. 2 

- New Outlook Features: David Gorelik presented the new Outlook features, including agility, consistency, and manageability. He explained how the new code base allows for faster updates and improvements, such as Copilot features and editorial content enhancements. 3 

- Shared Mailboxes: Caitlin Hart discussed the improvements in shared mailboxes, including the ability to see all shared items and manage settings like auto replies and categories. She highlighted the upcoming work to enhance the shared mailbox experience, making it better than the classic version. 4 

- Migration Planning: Caitlin Hart outlined the migration planning phases, including the opt-in phase starting in April 2026 and the cutover beyond 2029. She encouraged organizations to run pilot groups and control their own timing for migration to the new Outlook. 5 

- Add-ins Migration: Caitlin Hart addressed the migration of add-ins, focusing on security-related add-ins and partnering with top developers to bring COM add-in capabilities to the web platform. She recommended running pilots to identify necessary add-ins and provide feedback for further improvements. 6 

- Feedback Channels: Kelly raised concerns about the limitations of built-in feedback channels due to compliance policies. Caitlin Hart suggested using calls like this one, DCRs, and the product feedback page in the admin center to prioritize important features. 7 

- Security and Compliance: Mohun emphasized the importance of security and compliance features in the new Outlook, particularly for purview, DLP, and policy tips. Caitlin Hart assured that security is a high priority and recommended reviewing the new security white paper for detailed information. 8 

- Delegate Support: Jeffrey Frank inquired about delegate support and sync issues with mobile devices. Caitlin Hart explained that the new Outlook's architecture should resolve many of the sync issues and provided a resource overview for delegates. 9 

- Memory Consumption: Jeffrey Frank mentioned occasional high memory consumption warnings in the new Outlook. Caitlin Hart acknowledged the issue and assured that there is an ongoing work stream to improve memory performance and reduce such incidents. 10
Low-fidelity wireframe mocks to be used for conceptual work.

This component is the background that goes behind event cards. For Single/3-Day Views, this includes times stacked on left side, as well as "timeslot" lines (see sub-component "Empty Time Block").

Note: Month View uses individual cells for the days, instead of a vertical stack - should month view be a different component?

Reference work done for Android Components WIP

iOS has updated their default list style from full-width blocks, to inset blocks with rounded corners. Since we use the native list item style in Outlook iOS, this visual change was automatically updated in the app.  This means the iOS Design Kit is now out of date with the build.

Action Items

  1. Update kits to reflect this new list item style. Key areas of affect are Settings and Calendar areas, which use list items heavily.
  2. Sync with Fluent team and see if they will be updating the iOS Fluent Library to have this new style. If they aren't updating, Outlook will need to fork the styling and may need to create our own components, where necessary.
